messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Michael Feathers wrote:
>
> > So, (playing devil's advocate), we should treat them like babies? How
> > will they act when we do?
>
> They will learn the right way of doing things, just as children do when
> corrected.

Elliotte, you substituted "children" for "babies".

When we correct children, the goal isn't just to get them to do the
right thing, but also to develop their decision-making skills. This is
why, over time, we have to instruct and correct them less, and let them
make increasingly more and more important mistakes. They learn more from
that feedback than they learn from being corrected.

If we constantly relieve programmers of the responsibility of reading
the documentation or tests, then they will certainly never do it.

I suppose we need both camps: some API publishers who insist their users
act like adults and some API publishers who allow users to act like
babies. Without the former, all programmers settle to the level of
babies; and without the latter, not enough work gets done while waiting
for the babies to start thinking for themselves.

So perhaps this isn't and either/or scenario.
